newsitem.title: MALAWI: Taiwan gives Malawi $4 million for army.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan gives Malawi $4 million for army.

text.p: Taiwan on Wednesday donated $4 million to Malawi to build houses for the southern African country's soldiers.
Taiwanese Foreign Minister John Chang, who is on a official visit to Malawi, said his government would continue to help Malawi.
"We have proof that we are your trustworthy friend. You can count on us in time of need," Chang told Malawi President Bakili Muluzi during a meeting in Blantyre.

Chang said Taiwan -- competing with the People's Republic of China for relations with some African countries -- would abide by the commitments it had made to Malawi since 1965 when the two countries established diplomatic ties.
"The Republic of China will stand firm at your side," he said.
Muluzi said earlier that Malawi as a sovereign state wanted its bilateral relationship with Taiwan to continue.
"This relationship must continue for the betterment of our people. This relationship is based on solid foundation and we must make sure it continues," he said.
Muluzi said it was also the responsibility of his government to seek technical cooperation with Taiwan in agriculture, education, health and manufacturing.
The $4 million aid would be used to improve accommodation for Malawi soldiers. Some soldiers have been living in run-down barracks and others in rented housing.
